question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If there is no error, select ‘No error’ as your answer.
My brother / who live in Pune / is arriving tomorrow.

(SSC CGL 2020 T-1 : 20 August Shift 2 (12 to 1 PM))
solution:
Answer: who live in Pune

Solution:

  • The error lies in subject–verb agreement within the relative clause.

  • The antecedent “brother” is singular, so the verb must be “lives”, not “live.”

  • Correct form: “My brother who lives in Pune is arriving tomorrow.”

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.

One of these / boxes have / the portrait / of the heiress.

(SSC CGL 2023 T-1 : 20 July Shift-1)
solution:
Answer: a) boxes have
Solution:

  • The subject is "One of these boxes", which is singular, even though "boxes" is plural.

  • So, the verb should also be singular: "has", not "have".

  • Correct sentence: "One of these boxes has the portrait of the heiress."

heiress – a female who inherits wealth – उत्तराधिकारी महिला / वारिसा
portrait – a painting or picture of a person – चित्र / तस्वीर

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them contains an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options.
The Committee agreed / that small businesses / has been adversely affected / by COVID-19.

(SSC CGL 2020 T-1 : 24 August Shift 1 (9 to 10 AM))
solution:
Answer: has been adversely affected
Solution:
• The subject here is "small businesses", which is plural.
• Therefore, the correct verb form should be "have been", not "has been".
• Correct phrase: "have been adversely affected"

Correct sentence:
"The Committee agreed that small businesses have been adversely affected by COVID-19."

Grammar Rule:
Use "has" with singular subjects and "have" with plural subjects.
Here, "businesses" is plural → "have been" is required.

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
The historians / are a great / asset to the/ field of academia.

(SSC CGL 2023 T-1 : 24 July Shift-3)
solution:
Answer:(1) Assets to the

Solution:
The phrase “The historians are a great asset” is grammatically incorrect because “historians” is plural, and “a great asset” is singular. The correct phrase should be:

“The historians are great assets…” (plural form “assets”)

Corrected sentence:
“The historians are great assets to the field of academia.”

Word Meanings:

  • Historians – इतिहासकार

  • Asset – संपत्ति / उपयोगी वस्तु

  • Academia – अकादमिक क्षेत्र

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
Here / come / the bus / for Lucknow.

(SSC CGL 2023 T-1 : 25 July Shift-1)
solution:
Answer: come
Solution:

  • The sentence is: "Here / come / the bus / for Lucknow."

  • This sentence is in inversion form, which is common when using "Here" or "There" at the beginning.

  • But the subject is "the bus", which is singular, so the verb must also be singular: comes, not come.

  • Correct sentence: "Here comes the bus for Lucknow."

  • "Come" is a plural verb, used with plural subjects (e.g., Here come the boys).

  • So, segment 3 ("come") contains the error.

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
Despite the setbacks and obstacles we faced, / our team rallied together and achieved our goals, / which teach us the importance of / teamwork, resilience, and determination.

(SSC MTS 2023 : 4_Sept_Shift-2)
option_1: Despite the setbacks and obstacles we faced,
option_3: which teach us the importance of
option_4: our team rallied together and achieved our goals,
solution:
Answer: 3
Solution: The error is in the segment "which teach us the importance of".

The relative pronoun "which" refers to "our team" or "our team rallied together and achieved our goals", both of which are singular. Therefore, the verb should be "teaches" (singular), not "teach" (plural).

Correct sentence:
"Despite the setbacks and obstacles we faced, our team rallied together and achieved our goals, which teaches us the importance of teamwork, resilience, and determination."

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don’t find any error, mark ‘No error’ as your answer.
He are very thirsty. / Give him / a little water to drink.

(SSC CPO 2023 T-1 : 5 Oct Shift-2 (12_30 to 2_30 PM))
option_2: a little water to drink
solution:
The error is in the part: "He are very thirsty."

the subject "He" requires the singular form of the verb, which is "is." Therefore, the correct form of the sentence is "He is very thirsty."

question:
Identify the error in tense and choose the correct form of the verb in present tense from the following options.
My teacher often forget the name of students.

(SSC CPO 2023 T-1 : 5 Oct Shift-2 (12_30 to 2_30 PM))
solution:
The error in tense is in the verb "forget".

The correct form of the verb in present tense is: forgets

the correct form of the verb in present tense should be "forgets" to match the subject "My teacher" and to convey the habitual nature of the action.

Therefore, the corrected sentence would be: "My teacher often forgets the name of students."

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
Both Reeta and Ronika / has won / the dance competition / this year.

(SSC CGL 2022 T-1 : 6 Dec Shift-4)
solution:
Answer: has won

Explanation:

  • A compound subject (संयुक्त कर्ता) like “Both Reeta and Ronika” is plural (बहुवचन), so it needs a plural verb (बहुवचन क्रिया).

  • “has” is a singular (एकवचन) form, but with a plural subject you must use “have.”

  • The incorrect segment “has won” therefore violates subject–verb agreement (क्रिया–कर्ता का मेल).

  • Correct sentence: “Both Reeta and Ronika have won the dance competition this year.”

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
They all, except Shirin, were very sad / during the farewell party given / to the teacher retiring, and her / indifference were well noticed.

(SSC CGL 2022 T-1 : 7 Dec Shift-3)
option_1: They all, except Shirin, were very sad
option_3: during the farewell party given
option_4: to the teacher retiring, and her
solution:
Answer: indifference were well noticed

Explanation:
The noun “indifference” is singular, so it must agree with a singular verb. It should read “indifference was well noticed,” not “were.”

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
My younger daughter, / Kanu prefer / dark chocolate / to yoghurt.

(SSC MTS 2023 : 8_Sept_Shift-1)
solution:
Answer: (2) Kanu prefer
Solution:
• The subject "Kanu" is singular, so the verb should be in the singular form
• The correct verb form is "prefers", not "prefer"
• Correct phrase: "Kanu prefers"

Correct sentence:
"My younger daughter, Kanu, prefers dark chocolate to yoghurt."

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
Children listens to people / speaking around them / for a long time before / they begin to speak.

(SSC CGL 2022 T-1 : 9 Dec Shift-2)
option_3: for a long time before
solution:
Answer: Children listens to people

Explanation:
The error is a subject–verb agreement mistake: the plural noun children must take the base form listen, not the singular listens. The rest of the sentence is correct.

  • “Children” is plural → verb should be “listen”

  • “Listens” is third-person singular and doesn’t agree with “children”

question:
Parts of the following sentence have been given as options. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don’t find any error, mark ‘No error’ as your answer.
My mother give me fresh carrot juice every evening.

(SSC CPO 2024 T-2 (8 Mar))
solution:
Explanation:

  • The subject "My mother" is singular, so the verb must also be singular.

  • "Give" is plural; the correct singular form is "gives."

✅ Correct sentence:
My mother gives me fresh carrot juice every evening.

question:
Parts of the given sentence have been given as options. One of them contains a grammatical error. Select the option that has the error.
The captain along with all the sailors were warmly welcomed back home by the town people.

(SSC CPO 2023 T-2)
option_3: along with all the sailors were
solution:
Solution:
The error is in the segment "along with all the sailors were". When the subject is joined by "along with", "together with", or "as well as", the verb agrees with the main subject, not the phrase that follows. Here, the main subject is "The captain", which is singular, so the verb should be "was" instead of "were".
"The captain" is correct as the singular subject.
"warmly welcomed back home" is correct as the passive voice structure.
"by the town people." is correct as the agent in passive voice.
Correct sentence: "The captain along with all the sailors was warmly welcomed back home by the town people."
Answer: along with all the sailors were

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
The box containing / the apples from / the valleys of Kashmir were / thrown away by Gautam.

(SSC CPO 2022 T-2)
option_3: the valleys of Kashmir were
solution:
Solution:

  • The subject of the sentence is "The box containing the apples from the valleys of Kashmir."

  • "The box" is singular, so the verb should be singular ("was," not "were").

  • The segment "the valleys of Kashmir were" incorrectly uses "were" instead of "was."

  • Therefore, the error lies in the segment: "the valleys of Kashmir were."

Answer: (c) the valleys of Kashmir were

question:
Parts of the following sentence have been given as options. Select the option that contains an error.
It will take us five and a half hours to reach Jaipur, is it?

(SSC CPO 2024 T-2 (30 April))
option_2: five and a half hours
solution:
Solution:

  • The sentence:
    "It will take us five and a half hours to reach Jaipur, is it?"

  • The error is in: "is it?"

  • Explanation:

  • This is a question tag attached to a statement.

  • The main statement is in future tense: "It will take us..."

  • The correct question tag for "It will..." is "won't it?"

  • Rule: If the main clause is affirmative with "will," the tag should be negative: "won’t it?"

  • Correct sentence:
    "It will take us five and a half hours to reach Jaipur, won’t it?"

  • Why the other parts are correct:

  • "It will take us", "five and a half hours", and "to reach Jaipur" – all grammatically correct.

Part with the error:
"is it?"

question:
The given sentence is divided into four segments. Select the option that has the segment with a grammatical error.
He organises / a children’s fair every year / and his friends comes / to attend it.

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-1 (02-July Shift 1))
option_4: a children’s fair every year
solution:
The segment with the grammatical error is: "and his friends comes."

Explanation:

  • The subject "his friends" is plural, so the verb should be "come" instead of "comes".

The corrected sentence would be:
"He organises a children’s fair every year and his friends come to attend it."

Thus, the correct answer is "and his friends comes."

question:
The following sentence has been divided into four segments. Identify the segment that contains an error.
They have decided / to wind out / their business / without delay.

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-1 (02-July Shift 1))
solution:
The segment with the error is: "to wind out."

Explanation:

  • The correct phrase should be "to wind up" instead of "to wind out." "Wind up" means to bring something, such as a business, to an end or conclusion. "Wind out" is not a correct phrase in this context.

Thus, the corrected sentence should be: "They have decided to wind up their business without delay."

So, the correct answer is "to wind out."

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
I noticed that they / did not went to / the museum but entered / a shopping complex.

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-1 (02-July Shift 2))
solution:
The segment that contains a grammatical error is "did not went to".

Explanation:

  • The correct form is "did not go to". In negative sentences using "did," the verb should be in its base form (i.e., "go," not "went").

  • The corrected sentence should be: "I noticed that they did not go to the museum but entered a shopping complex."

Thus, the answer is "did not went to".

question:
The following sentence has been divided into four parts. Identify the part that contains an error.
Pratigya arrived / to the / railway station / five hours early.

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-1 (04-July Shift 3))
solution:
Answer: 2 (to the)

Explanation:
The verb "arrived" is generally followed by the preposition "at" when referring to places like a railway station.
Correct phrase: arrived at the railway station

Therefore, the segment with the error is "to the."

question:
Parts of the following sentence have been given as options. Select the option that contains an error.
Emily is a American living in Paris for her work.

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-1 (05-July Shift 1))
solution:
Correct Answer:a American

Explanation:

The article “a” is grammatically incorrect before a word that begins with a vowel sound.
“American” starts with a vowel sound (/ə/), so it should be preceded by “an”, not “a”.

✅ The corrected phrase should be: “an American”

Part of speech corrected:
Article (determiner) – "a" is replaced with "an" for correct usage before a vowel sound.

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains an error.
If she exercises daily, / she would / remain energetic / and fit forever.

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-1 (05-July Shift 3))
solution:
Correct Answer:she would

Explanation:

The sentence uses “If she exercises daily” (present tense), so the second clause should use the simple future (“will”) — not “would”, which is used in hypothetical or unreal conditions.

🔁 Correct form: “she will remain energetic and fit forever.”

This is a first conditional sentence:
If + present tense, will + base verb

Part of speech corrected:
Modal verb – "would" is replaced by "will" to match the real conditional structure.

question:
Parts of the following sentence have been given as options. Select the option that contains an error.
During winters, most of the trains are not running on time in North India.

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-1 (08-July Shift 2))
option_1: on time in North India.
solution:
Correct Answer:are not running

Explanation:

The error lies in "are not running", which is in the present continuous tense. However, the sentence talks about a habitual or regular occurrence during winters, so the simple present tense should be used instead.

  • ❌ "are not running" (present continuous – implies it is happening now)

  • ✅ "do not run" (simple present – correctly expresses a repeated or habitual action)

Correct sentence:
"During winters, most of the trains do not run on time in North India."

question:
Parts of the following sentence have been given as options. Select the option that contains an error.
There’s an quiet street down the left that you can use for your dance practice.

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-1 (08-July Shift 3))
solution:
Correct Answer: There’s an quiet street

Explanation:

  • The error lies in the article “an” used before the word “quiet.”

  • “Quiet” begins with a consonant sound (/kw/), not a vowel sound.

  • Therefore, the correct article should be “a” not “an.”

✅ Correct sentence: There’s a quiet street down the left that you can use for your dance practice.

Rule Recap:

  • Use “a” before words starting with a consonant sound (e.g., a quiet place, a house).

  • Use “an” before words starting with a vowel sound (e.g., an honest man, an apple).

question:
The following sentence has been divided into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
She / did not watched / Frankenstein / last night.

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-1 (09-July Shift 3))
solution:
Correct Answer: did not watched

Part of Speech of Corrected Part:

  • watched → should be watch (verb, base form after auxiliary "did")

Explanation:
When using the auxiliary "did" in negative sentences, the main verb should be in its base form without "ed."

Correct sentence:
"She did not watch Frankenstein last night."

So, the segment with the grammatical error is:
"did not watched."

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains an error.
Shall have / you bring / your note-book / tomorrow?

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-1 (10-July Shift 3))
solution:
Correct Answer: Shall have

Explanation:
The segment "Shall have" is grammatically incorrect in this interrogative sentence.

The correct structure for making a polite request or suggestion in the future is:
"Shall I have you bring..." or more naturally, "Will you bring..."

In this sentence, the intended meaning is likely a request or command:
✅ "Will you bring your notebook tomorrow?"

So, the segment with the error is: "Shall have".

question:
Parts of the following sentence have been underlined and given as options. Select the option that contains an error.
P̲o̲l̲i̲c̲e̲m̲a̲n̲ came to m̲y̲ ̲v̲i̲l̲l̲a̲g̲e̲ and asked about a̲ ̲p̲e̲r̲s̲o̲n̲ ̲who burgled a̲ ̲h̲o̲u̲s̲e̲ last night.

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-1 (11-July Shift 1))
solution:
Correct Answer: policeman

Explanation:
The word "policeman" should be preceded by an article "The" or "A" depending on the context, but in this sentence, it is missing the article altogether, which is grammatically incorrect.

Correct usage:
"The policeman came to my village..." or "A policeman came to my village..."

The other parts:

  • my village – Correct

  • a person – Correct

  • a house – Correct

So, the segment with the error is:
"policeman" (missing article).

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
It is his job / to chase out / clients with / outstanding debts.

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-1 (11-July Shift 2))
solution:
Correct Answer: to chase out

Part of Speech of Corrected Part:

  • to chase (infinitive verb)

  • away (adverb, should be added for correctness)

Explanation:
The phrase "to chase out" is awkward here. The correct phrasal verb is "to chase away," meaning to drive away or remove.

Correct phrase:
"to chase away clients with outstanding debts."

So, the segment with the grammatical error is:
"to chase out."

question:
The following sentence has been divided into four segments. One of them contains an error. Select the segment that contains the error from the given options.
Neither Smith / nor Rose / were in / the classroom.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.1_30-Sep_Shift-1)
solution:
Correct Answer: were in

Explanation:
When using "Neither...nor" with singular subjects (Smith and Rose), the verb should be singular.

  • "were" is plural and incorrect here.

  • The correct verb is "was".

Correct sentence:
"Neither Smith nor Rose was in the classroom."

Part of speech with error: Verb (incorrect number agreement).

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
My secretary is disposed of / discuss everything in great detail / before she begins / the actual work.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.1_30-Sep_Shift-1)
option_3: discuss everything in great detail
option_4: My secretary is disposed of
solution:
Correct Answer: My secretary is disposed of

Explanation:
The phrase "disposed of" means "got rid of" or "threw away," which does not fit the intended meaning here. The correct phrase should be "disposed to" or "disposed towards," meaning "inclined to" or "tends to."

Correct sentence:
"My secretary is disposed to discuss everything in great detail before she begins the actual work."

Part of speech with error:
Phrasal verb/verb phrase — incorrect usage of "disposed of."

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
The brave and courageous soldiers / of our motherland / fell into the enemy / and won the battle.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.14_09-Oct_Shift-3)
option_1: The brave and courageous soldiers
solution:
Correct Answer: fell into the enemy

Explanation:

  • The phrase "fell into the enemy" is incorrect because the preposition "into" is not suitable when referring to an attack on people.

  • You can fall into something like a trap, hole, or confusion, but not "into" the enemy.

  • The correct phrase is "fell upon the enemy", which means attacked the enemy suddenly and forcefully.

  • "Fell upon" is a phrasal verb commonly used in military or combat contexts.

  • The error lies in the misuse of the preposition "into" with the noun "enemy", which should instead take "upon".

question:
Parts of the following sentence have been given as options. Select the option that contains an error.
A fox and an hyena were spotted in the animal reserve.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.20_15-Oct_Shift-3)
solution:
Correct Answer: and an hyena

Explanation:
The error lies in "an hyena". The article "an" is used before words that begin with a vowel sound, not just a vowel letter.

"Hyena" begins with a consonant sound (the "h" is pronounced), so the correct article is "a" — not "an".

Correct sentence: A fox and a hyena were spotted in the animal reserve.

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
Most probably, / he come / to office / next Tuesday.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.25_17-Oct_Shift-2)
solution:
Answer: he come

Explanation:
The phrase "he come" is grammatically incorrect because the verb does not agree with the singular subject "he."

  • Correct form: "he comes" (present simple tense for third person singular) or "he will come" (future tense).

Other segments are correct.

Correct sentence:
"Most probably, he will come to office next Tuesday."

question:
Parts of the following sentence have been given as options. Select the option that contains an error.
Rose painted the most beautifullest picture ever at the art class today!

(SSC MTS 2024 S.26_17-Oct_Shift-3)
solution:
Answer: the most beautifullest

Explanation:
The phrase "most beautifullest" is incorrect because it is a double superlative.

  • The correct superlative form of "beautiful" is "most beautiful" or "most beautiful", not "beautifullest."

Correct phrase:
"the most beautiful"

Other parts of the sentence are grammatically correct.

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don’t find any error, mark ‘No error’ as your answer.
It is a fact that / girls' hair is usually / long than the boys' hair.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.29_18-Oct_Shift-3)
option_1: long than the boys' hair
option_2: It is a fact that
solution:
Answer: long than the boys' hair

Explanation:
The correct comparative structure should be "longer than the boys' hair" instead of "long than the boys' hair."

Correct sentence:
"It is a fact that girls' hair is usually longer than the boys' hair."

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
In accordance to / the factual data, / serious measures are required / to control the loss.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.3_30-Sep_Shift-3)
solution:
Correct answer:In accordance to

Explanation:

The phrase “in accordance to” is grammatically incorrect.
The correct prepositional phrase is “in accordance with.”

Let’s analyze each segment:

  • In accordance to – ❌ incorrect; the standard usage is “in accordance with”

  • The factual data – ✅ grammatically correct

  • Serious measures are required – ✅ correct passive construction

  • To control the loss – ✅ grammatically correct infinitive phrase

Correct sentence:
"In accordance with the factual data, serious measures are required to control the loss."

"With" is the correct preposition that follows "in accordance."

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
He sings good / among all the / contestants in / the singing competition.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.30_21-Oct_Shift-1)
solution:
Answer: He sings good

Explanation:

  • The correct adverb form should be "well" instead of "good" when describing how someone sings.

  • "Good" is an adjective, while "well" is an adverb used to describe actions.

Correct sentence:
"He sings well among all the contestants in the singing competition."

question:
The following sentence contains an error. Select the option that correctly rectifies the error.
If I was a king, I would have tried my best to remove poverty from my country.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.34_22-Oct_Shift-2)
option_1: If I were a king,
option_2: my best by remove poverty
solution:
Answer:If I were a king,

Explanation:
In hypothetical or imaginary situations (especially those that are unreal or contrary to fact), we use "were" instead of "was", even with "I", "he", or "she". This is a part of the subjunctive mood in English grammar.

The sentence is imagining something unreal — "If I were a king" (but I am not).

Correct Sentence:
If I were a king, I would have tried my best to remove poverty from my country.

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
She received / an award / for her work / in a engineering field.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.36_23-Oct_Shift-1)
solution:
Answer:in a engineering field.

Explanation:
The article "a" is incorrect before "engineering" because "engineering" starts with a vowel sound. The correct article is "an".

Correct Sentence:
She received an award for her work in an engineering field.

question:
Select the option that corrects the error in the given sentence.
She performed bad in the exam.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.49_04-Nov_Shift-2)
solution:
Answer: c) badly

Explanation:
The sentence is: "She performed bad in the exam."
Here, the word "performed" is a verb, and it must be modified by an adverb, not an adjective.

  • Badly = adverb of "bad", used to describe how something was done (बुरा तरीके से) → Correct choice

  • Bad = adjective (बुरा) → incorrect in this context

  • Good = adjective (अच्छा) → wrong meaning and form

  • Goodly = means large in amount or size (विशाल), and is outdated or rarely used

Correct sentence:
"She performed badly in the exam."

question:
In the following sentence the underlined part contains an error. Alternatives to the underlined part are given as options. Select the correct alternative.
The children were m̲e̲r̲r̲y̲ than usual on Sunday.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.5_01-Oct_Shift-2)
solution:
Correct answer:merrier

Explanation:

The sentence is:
“The children were merry than usual on Sunday.”

We are comparing the children’s mood on Sunday to their mood on other days, so we need the comparative degree of the adjective "merry."

Let’s evaluate the options:

  • Merrier – ✅ correct comparative form of "merry"

  • More merrier – ❌ incorrect; double comparison (more + -er) is grammatically wrong

  • Merriest – ❌ superlative form, used when comparing more than two, not suitable here

  • The merriest – ❌ again, superlative; not appropriate for a two-time comparison

So, the correct replacement is merrier, and the corrected sentence should be:
“The children were merrier than usual on Sunday.”

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don’t find any error, mark ‘No error’ as your answer.
Yesterday, / my surgeon / operate on my knee.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.52_05-Nov_Shift-2)
solution:
Answer: b) operate on my knee

Explanation:
The verb form after "my surgeon" (third person singular) should be "operated" or "operated on" in the past tense.

Correct sentence:
"Yesterday, my surgeon operated on my knee."

  • "Operate" is the base form; it should be in past tense "operated" to agree with "Yesterday" (past time).

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
The gold watch / look really expensive / and is not affordable / for common people.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.7_07-Oct_Shift-2)
solution:
Correct answer: look really expensive

Explanation:

  • The subject "The gold watch" is singular, so the verb must also be singular.

  • "look" is a plural verb. The correct singular form is "looks".

  • So, the correct sentence should be:
    "The gold watch looks really expensive and is not affordable for common people."

This error is in subject-verb agreement.

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
We / has seen / that movie / before.

(SSC CGL 2023 T-2 (26 Oct))
solution:
The correct answer is option c.

“Has seen”this is where the error is: "have seen" - This is the correct verb tense. "Have seen" is the present perfect tense, which is appropriate for an action that started in the past and has relevance to the present.
